{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3267963,"name":"Dan Nichols","username":"jnicho15","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnicho15/{size}/7893_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T17:06:28.091Z","cooked":"

Has anyone else had issues with ferrules and the power inputs of the radio power module?

Multiple times using the recommended uninsulated ferrules, stress on the wire (of course our fault) has caused the wire to perfectly break at the end of the ferrule, leaving the ferrule stuck in the wago connector. Trying to fish out the stuck ferrule isn’t very fun and often results in damage to the connector.

We’ve started to switch to insulated ferrules so that we have something to grab on, but that doesn’t work for the really-tiny connectors like on the pneumatic hub.

I looked on DigiKey for replacement terminals to repair our damaged ones, but it doesn’t look like they are available in red/black, only gray. Looks like per the rules as long as the replacement parts have the same specs, we can use ones that don’t match.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-12-21T17:06:28.091Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":136.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":446711,"topic_slug":"radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness","display_username":"Dan Nichols","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23941,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness/446711/1","custom_user_title":"FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3267972,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T17:35:12.765Z","cooked":"

We have always just used bare stranded tinned copper and have never had an issue. I would recommend using the stranded wire without a ferrule to reduce the chance of this kind of failure.

One less connector in the chain is a good thing.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-12-21T18:00:52.816Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":39.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":446711,"topic_slug":"radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness","display_username":"Cory Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":43759,"username":"Emerson1706","name":"Emerson OHara","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22243,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness/446711/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3268011,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T19:02:01.005Z","cooked":"
jnicho15:

Multiple times using the recommended uninsulated ferrules, stress on the wire (of course our fault) has caused the wire to perfectly break at the end of the ferrule, leaving the ferrule stuck in the wago connector.

I know those wires are small (and the connectors are small) but some strain relief is going to help you in the long run. You’re getting substantial wire movement which is concentrating all the movement right at the entry to the ferrule - before long, well, you know what happens before long.

I’d agree with some of the other posters that just using bare wire here will help but even with that, you’ve got to the vibration locked down.

Something like this can be a big win:

Wipe the surface clean with some isopropyl alcohol, let it dry, and if the adhesive is any good, this is gonna stay in place (consider getting name brand stuff at your local big box).

I’m empathetic to your ferrule / connector issue but that’s being driven by a lot of vibration and resulting movement.

[ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness/446711/4","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3268040,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T19:48:50.587Z","cooked":"
zog:

Something like this can be a big win:

A couple of installation tips for the OP.

  • tie down the wire close to the terminal. The shorter the distance the less the strain from hits.
  • mount the wire such that it is in a neutral position with no strain as inserted in the terminal. That is the terminal is not forcing the wire to a shape or position it would not otherwise be in.

There are some CD threads about the culture wars with and without data about ferrules or not and bare or tinned. Follow the rules of adequate tie downs and not pre-stressed and the end dressing almost doesn’t matter. (Bare wire might conform to terminal jaws better for less resistance but ferrule manufacturers have data supporting their products for many cases.)

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-12-21T19:48:50.587Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":446711,"topic_slug":"radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness/446711/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3268076,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T21:32:08.211Z","cooked":"
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Follow the rules of adequate tie downs and not pre-stressed and the end dressing almost doesn’t matter.

I’m totally with @SLAB-Mr.Thomas here - the real killer isn’t the termination, it’s the movement that causes the stress on the wire(s). Too much movement will destroy pretty much any termination from the practical perspective.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-12-21T21:32:20.463Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":27.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":446711,"topic_slug":"radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness/446711/6","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3268079,"name":"Dan Nichols","username":"jnicho15","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnicho15/{size}/7893_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T21:42:21.858Z","cooked":"

Yeah, we need to properly strain relieve the connections. I was trying to move beyond that. IF we do a bad job and the wire gets yanked/breaks from work hardening, THEN the end-result has a greater chance of leaving the component inoperable if uninsulated ferrules are used in something like these spring terminals.

Tinning might be an option but, if anything, seems to be generally known to create a more-significant stress concentration where the solder ends, versus a crimp. Regardless all of these connection techniques are transmitting all mechanical stress through the conductors, unlike a JST or “PWM” crimp terminal which grabs the insulation as well.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-12-21T21:43:55.885Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":59,"readers_count":58,"score":16.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":446711,"topic_slug":"radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness","display_username":"Dan Nichols","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":40142,"username":"zog","name":"Chris Herzog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23941,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/radio-power-module-input-terminal-robustness/446711/7","custom_user_title":"FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3268082,"name":"kgzak","username":"kgzak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kgzak/{size}/157079_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-21T21:52:57.860Z","cooked":"

I was constantly fishing broken ferrules out of the old Weidmuller connectors. Wasn’t a fun time. I have found the wago connectors tend to hold the bare wire much better than the weidmullers did so we don’t use many ferrules anymore.

In my experience too tight of crimps can cause the wires to break easily. Especially on small gauge wire.
